@Louboui , Anything left on an exchange (Bitcoin or XRP) is no longer under your control and Coinbase, for example, could decide to freeze your account.

“The consensus mechanism for the Devs and the protocol allows them to make it where they can unilaterally update and lock it” The source code for the XRP Ledger is open. Please point to the code that allows such a thing. You may start here: https:// github.com/ripple/rippled

Incorrect. XRP cannot be locked or frozen. If you choose to leave your crypto on an exchange, Bitcoin or XRP, you’ve handed over your keys and control over that crypto. Coinbase can freeze a user acct, but that is not the same as crying “all BTC can be frozen by Coinbase.”
I don’t think Ripple has an API for XRP payment processing. Anybody can plug into the network for free. You don’t need Ripple’s permission to accept XRP.

8/ If #WarrenBuffett says he shouldn't establish a position in #bitcoin because he knows nothing about it, then why take a *position in opinion*?
6/ I would really appreciate if #crypto commentators clarified their time frames, because on a long enough time-scale we are all right and wrong.
5/ Buffet will also, inevitably, be right. The current froth in the #crypto markets will end badly. But that doesn't mean it won't sprout again from the ashes.
4/ Buffet has been wrong about #crypto for a long time. He has missed out on a >40x move in the overall market over the last year. Multiples of that on a longer time frame.

What's frustrating about Buffet's comment on #crypto here: "I can say with almost certainty that they will come to a bad ending," is that I could have said the same about equities in the 20th century and been right *many times over* https://www. cnbc.com/2018/01/10/buf fetts-cryptocurrency-predictions-are-scary-heres-how-to-cope.html …
